data.sampled:
B. Yes, because the displayed frequency is within the 75 meter phone band segment.

The correct answer is B. According to the FCC rules, the 75-meter band segment consists of the frequencies from 3.600 to 3.650 MHz, which includes the displayed frequency of 3.601 MHz LSB. Therefore, it is legal to return the call using lower sideband on the same frequency. The answer A is incorrect because the DX station initiated the call, but it does not make a difference for whether it is legal for a U.S. station to use the same frequency in SSB mode. Answer C is incorrect because sideband emissions can extend beyond the band segment edges, but they are still within the 75-meter band. Answer D is incorrect because U.S. stations are allowed to use phone emissions within the 75-meter band, and 3.601 MHz LSB falls within that range.

The maximum power output permitted on the 60 meter band is 50 watts PEP effective radiated power relative to an isotropic radiator.

This applies to both amateur and commercial radio operations on the 60 meter band, which is 5.351.5 to 5.406.5 MHz (excluding the specific frequencies listed in the FCC rules). The power limit is intended to prevent interference to other services and stations within the band.

An amateur station transmitting Slow Scan TV is allowed only on the following frequencies: 145.64 and 155.64 MHz; 420.1, 420.6, 421.8, 223.0, 224.0, 224.5, 225.5 and 226.0 MHz. Additional frequencies are also available to be used if both the transmitting and receiving station can support their use. However, if other amateur stations cannot properly receive transmissions due to technical limitations on their part, the station transmitting the SSTV is allowed to relocate to other frequencies without causing harmful interference.

To answer the question on the FCC Amateur Radio License test; "B" is the correct response.

Practice multiple-choice question with answer explanation:

A. Frequency band segments below 50 MHz are available to non-technician class licensees for phone and CW emissions, and are used exclusively for voice communications.
B. Frequency band segments below 50 MHz are available to Technician Class licensees for voice, data, and image transmission.
C. Voice and telegraph emissions include phone, CW, and RTTY.
D. Automatic Power Control (APC) is an automatic system that periodically compares the amplitude of the received signal to a known reference level and adjusts the output power accordingly. Technician Class licensees may operate using APC, but are not authorized to install or service any equipment employing APC.

data.sampled:
B. You must submit engineering drawings to the FAA.

The correct answer is "B." According to the FCC rules (Section 97.15(c)(4)), if you are installing a station antenna at a site at or near a public use airport, you must "submit technical information necessary for an evaluation of the proposed facility to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)."
The technical information that you must submit includes "appearance, height, location, effective radiated power, directionality, polarization, shielding, type of antenna, and other relevant characteristics of the proposed antenna."
The FAA may use this information to evaluation the impact that the proposed facility may have on air navigation, as well as other potential hazards that could exist at the airport. It is important to note that this regulation applies to both fixed and mobile amateur stations at or near airports (Sec. 97.15(c)(4)).

(Source: http://www.arrl.org/amateur-radio-regulations-in-the-united-states)


As to how you should study the test,
In addition to using study guides, it’s a good idea to become familiar with the FCC rules and regulations pertaining to the amateur radio service. This can be done by reviewing the FCC Rules and Regulations section on the FCC website, as well as reading articles and publications from amateur radio organizations such as the ARRL.

Another resource that can be useful for studying for the Amateur Radio exams is online quiz pool. These contain additional questions, some of which are not included in the official study guide. In some cases, these online quizzes also provide detailed explanations and references to the rules and regulations so that you can understand why the answer you chose was correct or incorrect

If you want to consult more multiple-choice questions, my suggestion is that you use the website: [FCC Amateur Radio Question Pool for Element 2 Technician Class](https://www.ncvec.org/#questionPool%29. What is the maximum output power an amateur station may use when operating in the 30-, 17-, and 12-meter bands?
A. 200 watts PEP
B. 400 watts PEP
C. 1500 watts PEP
D. 15 watts PEP

A. 200 watts PEP.

What operating practice is permitted in phone emission mode on amateur frequencies?
A. Maximum of 30 minutes per session.
B. Minimum of 30 minutes per session.
C. Maximum of three consecutive transmissions of up to two minutes per transmission.
D. Minimum of three consecutive transmissions of up to two minutes per transmission.

A. Maximum of 30 minutes per session.

What emission may be used for telegraphy in the frequency range 380 to 400 kHz and for digital communications using only a telegraph key?
A. Phone emission.
B. CW emission.
C. AM emission.
D. Digital emission.

B. CW emission.

What kind of emission uses a two-carrier frequency technique for the transmission of audio frequency information?
A. SSB emission.
B. FM emission.
C. AM emission.
D. Digital emission.

A. SSB emission.

B. Half-duplex operation. {TX-RX(listen) simultaneously}
C. Duplex operation.
D. Splits operation.

data.sampled:
B. The amateur station operator must agree not to transmit when the main radio of the ship or aircraft is in use.

Here is the source:

<https://www.ncra.org/study_guides/FCC_Study_Guide_for_Amateur_Radio_License_Tests/Introduction_to_ Licenses_and_Operation/Operating_an_Amateur_Station_Aboard_a_Vessel_or_Aircraft/2_2_10.html>.

According to the FCC rules, "The amateur station operator must agree not to transmit when the main radio of the ship or aircraft is in use" (B). This is a requirement for operating an amateur station aboard a ship or aircraft. The FCC rules also recognize that operating amateur stations aboard ships and aircraft is useful for radio communication in emergency situations and for training and experimentation in communications by qualified and technically skilled personnel. Operating an amateur station aboard a ship or aircraft can also "serve the public by making additional radio channels available for public service in time of emergency or disaster" ({cf.}(https://www.ncra.org/study_guides/FCC_Study_Guide_for_Amateur_Radio_License_Tests/Introduction_to_Licenses_and_Operation/Operating_an_Amateur_Station_Aboard_a_Vessel_or_Aircraft/2_2_10.html)).

In addition to agreeing not to transmit when the main radio of the ship or aircraft is in use, the amateur operator must have at least a Technician Class license to operate in the amateur bands that are covered by the ITU region 2 band plan. If the ship or aircraft leaves the ITU region 2 region

A. Its operation must be approved by the master of the ship or the pilot in command of the aircraft

C. The amateur station must have a power supply that is completely independent of the main ship or aircraft power supply
D. The amateur operator must have an FCC Marine or Aircraft endorsement on his or her amateur license
